discount.translation[2].definitions[1].d: the amount by which the price of a SECURITY is less than the value shown on it
discount.translation[2].definitions[1].e: Zero-coupon bonds are sold at a discount to their face value and pay no interest until maturity.
discount.translation[2].definitions[2].d: if a BILL OF EXCHANGE is traded at a fine rate of discount, it is bought and sold at a price near to the amount shown on it, because the buyer knows there is little risk of it not being paid
discount.translation[2].definitions[2].e: Accepting Houses accept bills of exchange for a fee, which enables the bill to be traded at a fine rate of discount.
discount.translation[2].definitions[3].d: if something in a financial market is traded at a discount, it is bought and sold at a lower price than something else to which it is compared
discount.translation[2].definitions[3].e: The premium of platinum over gold narrowed to $11, but there is a good chance platinum will trade at a discount to gold soon.
discount.translation[3].definitions[0].d: to offer something for sale at a lower price than usual
discount.translation[3].definitions[0].e: The retailers discounted the goods below prices set by the manufacturer.
Games were discounted to as little as $5.
discount.translation[3].definitions[1].d: to change the price of something in a financial market by taking into account good or bad news that affects it
discount.translation[3].definitions[1].e: I think the market has discounted almost all of what can go right with the economy this year.
discount.translation[3].definitions[2].d: to sell SECURITIES at less than the value shown on them. The person who buys the securities makes a profit when the borrower buys them back at their full value at the repayment date
discount.translation[3].definitions[3].d: to sell a BILL OF EXCHANGE or other COMMERCIAL BILL before its normal payment date for less than it will be worth on that date. The buyer makes a profit when the bill is paid in full by the borrower at the repayment date
